trans-unit.source: <properties pageTitle="Getting Started using docker with swarm on Azure" description="Describes how to create a group of VMs with the Docker VM Extension and use swarm to create a Docker cluster." services="virtual-machines" documentationCenter="virtual-machines" authors="squillace" manager="timlt" editor="tysonn"/>
trans-unit.target: <properties pageTitle="Getting Started using docker with swarm on Azure" description="Describes how to create a group of VMs with the Docker VM Extension and use swarm to create a Docker cluster." services="virtual-machines" documentationCenter="virtual-machines" authors="squillace" manager="timlt" editor="tysonn"/>

trans-unit.source: <tags ms.service="virtual-machines" ms.devlang="na" ms.topic="article" ms.tgt_pltfrm="vm-linux" ms.workload="infrastructure" ms.date="05/24/2015" ms.author="rasquill"/>
trans-unit.target: <tags ms.service="virtual-machines" ms.devlang="na" ms.topic="article" ms.tgt_pltfrm="vm-linux" ms.workload="infrastructure" ms.date="05/24/2015" ms.author="rasquill"/>

trans-unit.source: This topic shows a very simple way to use <linkText>docker</linkText><title></title> with <linkText>swarm</linkText><title></title> to create a swarm-managed cluster on Azure.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows a very simple way to use <linkText>docker</linkText><title></title> with <linkText>swarm</linkText><title></title> to create a swarm-managed cluster on Azure.

trans-unit.source: It creates four virtual machines in Azure, one to act as the swarm manager, and three as part of the cluster of docker hosts.
trans-unit.target: It creates four virtual machines in Azure, one to act as the swarm manager, and three as part of the cluster of docker hosts.

trans-unit.source: When you are finished, you can use swarm to see the cluster and then begin to use docker on it.
trans-unit.target: When you are finished, you can use swarm to see the cluster and then begin to use docker on it.

trans-unit.source: In addition, the Azure CLI calls in this topic use the service management (asm) mode.
trans-unit.target: In addition, the Azure CLI calls in this topic use the service management (asm) mode.

trans-unit.source: This is an early version of software, so check back for updates about using this on Azure to create large, balanced, and controlled clusters of Docker containers, as well as checking the docker swarm documentation to discover all its features.
trans-unit.target: This is an early version of software, so check back for updates about using this on Azure to create large, balanced, and controlled clusters of Docker containers, as well as checking the docker swarm documentation to discover all its features.

trans-unit.source: In addition, this topic uses docker with swarm and the Azure CLI without using docker-machine in order to show how the different tools work together but remain independent.
trans-unit.target: In addition, this topic uses docker with swarm and the Azure CLI without using docker-machine in order to show how the different tools work together but remain independent.

trans-unit.source: docker-machine has --swarm switches that enable you to use docker-machine to directly add nodes to a swarm.
trans-unit.target: docker-machine has --swarm switches that enable you to use docker-machine to directly add nodes to a swarm.

trans-unit.source: For an example, see the <linkText>docker-machine</linkText><title></title> documentation.
trans-unit.target: For an example, see the <linkText>docker-machine</linkText><title></title> documentation.

trans-unit.source: If you missed docker-machine running against Azure VMs, see How to use docker-machine with Azure.
trans-unit.target: If you missed docker-machine running against Azure VMs, see How to use docker-machine with Azure.

trans-unit.source: This topic creates four VMs, but you can use any number you want.
trans-unit.target: This topic creates four VMs, but you can use any number you want.

trans-unit.source: Call the following with <password> replaced by the password you have chosen.
trans-unit.target: Call the following with <password> replaced by the password you have chosen.

trans-unit.source: When you're done you should be able to use azure vm list to see your Azure VMs:
trans-unit.target: When you're done you should be able to use azure vm list to see your Azure VMs:

trans-unit.source: This topic uses the container model of installation from the docker swarm documentation -- but you could also SSH to the swarm-master.
trans-unit.target: This topic uses the container model of installation from the docker swarm documentation -- but you could also SSH to the swarm-master.

trans-unit.source: In this model, swarm is downloaded as a docker container running swarm.
trans-unit.target: In this model, swarm is downloaded as a docker container running swarm.

trans-unit.source: Below, we perform this step remotely from our laptop by using docker to connect to the swarm-master VM and tell it to use the cluster id creation command, swarm create.
trans-unit.target: Below, we perform this step remotely from our laptop by using docker to connect to the swarm-master VM and tell it to use the cluster id creation command, swarm create.

trans-unit.source: The cluster id is how swarm discovers the members of the swarm group.
trans-unit.target: The cluster id is how swarm discovers the members of the swarm group.

trans-unit.source: (You can also clone the repository and build it yourself, which will give you full control and enable debugging.)
trans-unit.target: (You can also clone the repository and build it yourself, which will give you full control and enable debugging.)

trans-unit.source: That last line is the cluster id; copy it somewhere because you will use it again when you join the node VMs to the swarm master to create the "swarm".
trans-unit.target: That last line is the cluster id; copy it somewhere because you will use it again when you join the node VMs to the swarm master to create the "swarm".

trans-unit.source: In this example, the cluster id is 36731c17189fd8f450c395db8437befd.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the cluster id is 36731c17189fd8f450c395db8437befd.

trans-unit.source: Just to be clear, we are using our local docker installation to connect to the swarm-master VM in Azure and instruction swarm-master to download, install, and run the create command, which returns our cluster id that we use for discovery purposes later.
trans-unit.target: Just to be clear, we are using our local docker installation to connect to the swarm-master VM in Azure and instruction swarm-master to download, install, and run the create command, which returns our cluster id that we use for discovery purposes later.

trans-unit.source: To confirm this, run docker -H tcp://<hostname> images to list the container processes on the swarm-master machine and on another node for comparison (because we ran the previous swarm command with the --rm switch, the container was removed after it finished, so using docker ps -a won't return anything).:
trans-unit.target: To confirm this, run docker -H tcp://<hostname> images to list the container processes on the swarm-master machine and on another node for comparison (because we ran the previous swarm command with the --rm switch, the container was removed after it finished, so using docker ps -a won't return anything).:

trans-unit.source: If you're familiar with docker, you'll know that the other nodes have no entries because no images have been downloaded and run yet.
trans-unit.target: If you're familiar with docker, you'll know that the other nodes have no entries because no images have been downloaded and run yet.

trans-unit.source: For each node, list the endpoint information using the Azure CLI.
trans-unit.target: For each node, list the endpoint information using the Azure CLI.

trans-unit.source: Below we do that for the swarm-node-1 docker host in order to obtain the node's docker port.
trans-unit.target: Below we do that for the swarm-node-1 docker host in order to obtain the node's docker port.

trans-unit.source: Using docker and the -H option to point the docker client at your node VM, join that node to the swarm you are creating by passing the cluster id and the node's docker port (the latter using --addr):
trans-unit.target: Using docker and the -H option to point the docker client at your node VM, join that node to the swarm you are creating by passing the cluster id and the node's docker port (the latter using --addr):

trans-unit.source: That looks good.
trans-unit.target: That looks good.

trans-unit.source: To confirm that swarm is running on swarm-node-1 we type:
trans-unit.target: To confirm that swarm is running on swarm-node-1 we type:

trans-unit.source: Repeat for all the other nodes in the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Repeat for all the other nodes in the cluster.

trans-unit.source: In our case, we do that for swarm-node-2 and swarm-node-3.
trans-unit.target: In our case, we do that for swarm-node-2 and swarm-node-3.

trans-unit.source: and then you can list out your nodes in your cluster:
trans-unit.target: and then you can list out your nodes in your cluster:

trans-unit.source: Go run things on your swarm.
trans-unit.target: Go run things on your swarm.

trans-unit.source: To look for inspiration, see <linkText>https://github.com/docker/swarm/</linkText><title></title>, or perhaps a <linkText>video</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To look for inspiration, see <linkText>https://github.com/docker/swarm/</linkText><title></title>, or perhaps a <linkText>video</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: virtual-machines-docker-machine.md
